[GRAMMAR]: Subject-verb agreement errors in "The astonishing progress... produced a whole literature of complacency."
Misplaced modifier in "The two tribes were a sufficient distance apart to prevent friction over their hunting-grounds..."
Subject-verb agreement error in "He remained in Nacogdoches because he found here a well-settled, hospitable Indian town..."
[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in "I quoted some examples of the language which was then common, in my Romanes Lecture on 'The Idea of Progress.'"
Awkward phrasing in "Having no written language with which to record the glories of their race..."
Awkward phrasing in "The story of Red Feather is delightfully recounted by Miss Adina de Zavala..."
Awkward phrasing in "One would not say that he was the greatest painter of his time--Gainsborough's gifts exceeded his in many directions..."
[SPELLING]: Inconsistent capitalization in "Red Feather taught his people the gentle arts of husbandry..."
[LEXICON]: Misuse of "vulgar language" in "The country was, in vulgar language, a going concern..."
[PUNCTUATION]: Missing comma after introductory phrase in "For the beginnings of Nacogdoches we must go back..."
Missing comma in "Among these were two children of the chief of the Hainai Indians, living near what is now known as the Goodman Crossing..."

[LOGIC]: Sudden shift from Nacogdoches history to English art in the eighteenth century with Joshua Reynolds.
Confusing reference to "English art in the eighteenth century" in the middle of a historical account of Nacogdoches.
Sudden shift from the Spanish settlement to the mention of the French cession of Louisiana.
[STRUCTURE]: Disjointed transition from the history of Nacogdoches to the mention of Bahá’u’lláh’s writings.
Disconnected paragraph about Joshua Reynolds that does not relate to the main narrative.
[CLARITY]: Unclear connection between the mention of LaSalle and the prior references to DeSoto and Coronado.
Unclear reference to "the information concerning its location has been preserved in the ancient Spanish parchments..." without context.
[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from the history of the Tejas Indians to the Spanish settlement in Nacogdoches.

[GRAMMAR]: "The city of Nacogdoches, as a civic corporation, dates from that year, in which that sturdy old Spaniard, Ybarbo, conducted his harassed and bewildered followers..." (awkward phrasing and comma splice)
"The population of the town were largely behind Lieutenant M. Musquiz..." (subject-verb agreement error)
[SYNTAX]: "The eastern boundary of Texas was at that time a shadowy, uncertain quantity, somewhere between the Sabine and Red rivers." (awkward phrasing)
"In the beginning of the new century the purchase of Louisiana by the United States from the French..." (awkward phrasing)
[LEXICON]: "The women folk, bored with high politics, would draw back the talk to the infant François..." (archaic or unclear phrasing)

[LOGIC]: Sudden shift from Ybarbo's governance to a narrative about "the women folk" and François, which is unrelated to the main historical narrative.
The narrative jumps between different historical events (Ybarbo's governance, Nolan's expedition, Louisiana purchase) without clear chronological or thematic links.
[STRUCTURE]: The transition from the founding of Nacogdoches to the Philip Nolan chapter is abrupt and lacks a clear connection.
[CLARITY]: The mention of "the infant François" is unclear and lacks context, disrupting the flow of the historical account.
[TRANSITION]: The shift from the investigation of Ybarbo to the Philip Nolan expedition lacks a smooth transition.
